Jeff Talley.Action: Speaks to the hostage-taker in a reasonable and friendly tone, tries to de-escalate the situation verbally rather than ordering immediate assault.
Refuses to give the tactical team the go-ahead to enter the house, insisting on negotiation first.
Takes a calm, reasonable, and friendly tone on the crisis phone to de-escalate the situation.
Speaks to Malik in a reasonable and friendly tone on the crisis phone, asking him not to kill the dog.
Frustrated when given bad information about Malik's wife being with her sister, but channels frustration to focus on the situation.
Abruptly grabs colleague Keith by the collar to get the dog's name, showing urgency and demand.
Steps into line of fire deliberately to be visible and maintain communication with Malik.
Tells Malik he did not lie about his wife, shows some honesty and tries to reason with him.
Encourages Malik to keep talking and engages him persistently to defuse the situation.
Questions intelligence officer when given bad info, insists on accurate information about the dog to build rapport with Malik.
Steps out from behind the command van into the line of fire to be seen, showing focus on negotiation despite risk.
Slumps back against the van showing frustration after bad intelligence, temporarily losing composure.
Calls out intelligence officer to get the dog's name to keep conversation going, demonstrating problem-solving ability.
Acknowledges Malik's pain and urges him not to give up, offering to have Malik's wife talk to him.
Grows concerned upon hearing Malik's odd wording and tries to communicate calmly, asking about the dog and redirecting Malik's attention.
Urgently communicates critical information to colleagues when he realizes Malik's wife is in danger.
Kneels between tactical cops and takes the boy's hand, stares into the boy's eyes in the face of tragedy.
Stares at the dead boy with numbness, overwhelmed by the traumatic scene.
Mars calmly tries to reassure Dennis by telling him to relax despite the tense situation.
Mars picks up the gun instead of fleeing, showing presence of mind to secure the weapon.
Mars steps between Dennis and Kevin to de-escalate their confrontation, exhibiting control.
Speaks gently and remorsefully on the phone, admitting the situation is difficult and not how he wants it.
Looks at family photos and asks for his daughter Amanda, showing care and connection despite pain.
Admits he is punishing himself and hiding from both the job and his family, indicating vulnerability and sincerity.
Seeks to talk more with his wife Jane when she comes over, showing desire to reconnect and communicate.
Develops a plan to cordon off the streets and evacuate houses in an active threat situation.
Uses his car as a shield to quickly reach and extract the wounded Mike Welch under fire.
Calmly manages communication on the radio by demanding one person speak at a time amid chaos.
Responds quickly to the urgent situation and improvises effectively without hesitation.
Forcefully calls for radio discipline to maintain order during chaos.
Shows concern about officers being pulled from a crime scene, wanting to maintain safety and proper coverage.
Internally troubled, staring at the hostage scene as if it were a terrible nightmare.
Calmly instructs officers to stabilize the situation and not let things get out of hand
Acknowledges the fear and inexperience of his officers but urges them to stay cool
Uses humor to lighten tension when Metzger questions how to maintain control
Focuses on operational details and managing the crisis rather than addressing emotional needs of hostages or officers
Delegates tasks efficiently by instructing officers to gather information about the suspect, showing organized investigative approach.
Recognizes and manages the impact of media presence on the situation, urging officers to remain calm and focused.
Acknowledges his leadership role and responsibility with confidence when reassuring Metzger.
Observes subordinates' inexperience and worries about their readiness, which may indicate some lack of confidence in team competence but not necessarily personal incompetence.
Calmly identifies himself and tries to establish communication with Dennis to defuse the situation.
Gently informs Dennis about Mr. Kim’s death, showing concern for honesty and transparency.
Tries to persuade Dennis to release hostages, prioritizing their safety.
Apologizes to Jane for not calling and explains the situation.
Talks calmly and informatively to Amanda, patiently answers her curious questions.
Focuses on gathering evidence and identifying the suspect by asking questions and observing details.
Observes and interprets the threatening behavior of Mars on the tape without emotional response.
Orders still prints to be made from tape and suggests showing the landlord for fast ID.
Notices and interprets the tattoo on Mars's head, showing attention to detail and knowledge.
Analyzes Mars's behavior on tape and correctly assesses him as seriously disturbed.
Explains situation calmly to Amanda and Jane, indicating situational awareness and communication skills.
Apologizes for lack of communication due to rapid developments.
Relies on Sheriff's takeover despite their delayed arrival.
Jane touches his arm, but Talley moves away self-consciously so he's out of reach.
Invites others to grab dinner and offers to meet them later despite his own stress.
Admits he is 'scared shitless' to Jane, showing vulnerability and sincerity.
Instructs Anders to call the City Attorney for a search warrant and organize search teams promptly.
Calls Jane to let her know he is almost home, showing concern for personal relationships.
No direct action or involvement in the scene; no evidence of competence or incompetence.
Greets incoming SWAT team politely, identifies himself, cooperates fully, and shares relevant tactical info.
Accepts orders from superiors without resistance and offers helpful support.
Refers to the kidnapper 'Rooney' as 'amped up and volatile' but warns not to crowd the house, showing concern for safety.
Tells officers to pull back and not breach the house to avoid bloodshed, expressing confidence in his ability to talk to the suspect.
Sprints toward the cul-de-sac to take command and intervene calmly despite the shooting chaos.
Calms the kidnappers by speaking quietly and carefully, assuring them no one will enter the house and things are under control.
Maintains calm and patience under pressure, trying to deescalate the situation and keep the hostage taker talking.
Directly tells Dennis that demands (helicopter) won't happen but encourages continued dialogue to avoid violence.
Speaks calmly and reassuringly to the hostage-taker, successfully calming him down and preventing immediate violence.
Recognizes when the situation is de-escalating and informs his team that the suspect is cooling off, showing good situational awareness.
Offers realistic, informed responses to the suspect's demands (e.g., explaining why a helicopter to Mexico won't happen), demonstrating knowledge and confidence.
Shares a personal and humorous secret ('I gotta piss real bad.') to lighten the mood with Dennis.
Engages in friendly banter with Martin, exchanging smiles and humor.
Maintains a grim, serious demeanor when addressing the threat of the gasoline, showing responsibility but limited emotional warmth in high-stakes moments.
Communicates clearly and with concern upon learning Jane is missing; instructs to keep trying and update.
Closes his eyes with a blissful expression while taking a moment in the bathroom, then immediately responds with concern and urgency to a radio message about a potentially compromised communication.
Responds quickly and attentively to unusual radio communication, switches from radio to phone as instructed, showing situational awareness and adaptability.
Takes a moment of calm (takes a piss) before responding promptly to radio call, indicating steady composure under pressure.
Does not hesitate or ignore the warning that others can hear the radio conversation, demonstrating good judgment about operational security.
Initially dismisses the boy's call as a crank but quickly reconsiders when presented with evidence, showing concern and willingness to listen.
Speaks gently and reassuringly to the frightened boy on the phone, encouraging him to slow down and talk calmly.
Checks in gently with Thomas multiple times, showing concern for his safety.
Offers to stay longer to help despite exhaustion.
Nods agreement to cautious approach suggested by Martin, showing trust and collaboration.
Leaves the scene to take a break, indicating self-care and trust in team.
Leaves a voice message for Jane and Mandy, showing concern by asking them to pick up.
Responds calmly to being held at gunpoint by telling them to 'Take it easy.'
States 'I'm the Chief. I don't carry it.' when asked about his gun.
Stays calm and does not move when unexpectedly held at gunpoint, knowing that sudden movements could worsen the situation.
Informs the gunmen he does not carry a gun as the Chief, signaling awareness and a disarming tactic rather than escalating tension.
Attempts to reach out to Jane and Mandy by phone before the event, demonstrating concern and attempt to communicate, though no one answers.
Does not take any visible evasive or defensive action when ambushed, which could be seen as a lack of assertiveness or preparation depending on context.
Responds with concern and panic upon hearing Jane's voice on the phone, showing deep care for family.
Remains communicative despite being physically restrained, indicating trust and willingness to engage.
Follows the Mustang obediently when instructed by The Watchman.
Keeps calm enough to understand the situation and communicates with The Watchman and Jane during the hostage situation.
Tries to resist physically by going berserk and bucking against his captors but fails to break free.
Eventually responds to The Watchman's question and agrees he can be let go, indicating some control over panic and shock.
Tells the Watchman he can let go despite being held tightly, showing trust and calmness under pressure.
Conveys that he cannot control the sheriffs running the scene, showing honesty and transparency.
Accepts responsibility to re-assume command and follow the Watchman's instructions to protect his family.
Despite being under extreme pressure and threat to his family, he calmly listens, asks clarifying questions, and focuses on gathering critical information (e.g., scratching down the license plate).
Admits he can't control the situation on the scene since sheriffs are running it, showing honesty about limits but reluctance or inability to assert authority.
Passively accepts the Watchman's demands to re-assume command from the sheriffs under threat, showing compliance but no immediate initiative or resistance.
Louise expresses concern for Talley's appearance and well-being; Talley barely acknowledges her and goes straight to his office.
Prepares carefully and meticulously for a dangerous situation, showing professionalism and responsibility.
Gives clear and direct instructions to Larry Anders and entrusts him with sensitive information, showing a degree of trustworthiness and concern for the operation's success.
Worries internally whether he can trust Anders and fears for the safety of his wife and child.
Instructs Anders firmly not to tell anyone about the investigation.
Re-assumes command decisively to get Smith out of the house.
Uses a dedicated crisis phone line to communicate covertly with Dennis inside the house, showing resourcefulness and tactical communication.
Decides to change his mind without explaining his reasoning to Maddox, potentially withholding information but demonstrating decisiveness.
Calms Dennis when he is near breaking point, coaxing him gently to communicate.
Pushes Dennis and Maddox aggressively at first, risking escalating tension.
Acknowledges Dennis's admission with understanding and positive reinforcement.
Appeals to Dennis's reason and hopes for saving a life, showing trust and sincerity.
Persuades Dennis to save Walter’s life, appealing to Dennis’s self-interest in court.
Calmly instructs paramedics and officers to proceed carefully and without escalating tension.
Chooses to approach Walter Smith himself along with paramedic to assist the injured hostage.
Does not express anger or frustration after Dennis curses at him on the phone.
Helps Bigelow carry Walter on the stretcher despite tense circumstances.
Glances back at Mars's eyes, acknowledging the silent communication without hostility.
Refuses to explain the situation to Maddox, saying 'No.'
Ignores the doctor's medical authority and shakes Walter's face to wake him, showing determination to help.
Grabs the doctor’s arm to insist on keeping time with Walter despite medical objections.
Steps up into the ambulance and insists on talking to the injured man despite medical warnings, shakes him awake, showing urgency and focus in a crisis.
Ignores the physician's medical concerns and physically shakes an injured man potentially worsening his condition.
Moves quickly to put on his clothes and take control of the situation after carrying the stretcher away, demonstrating decisiveness and readiness.
Grips Klaus's arm to try to make him understand and insists on asking one question, showing persistence and concern.
Pounds on the ambulance wall and shouts to stop the engine, expressing urgency and frustration but also care about the situation.
Pulls Metzger aside to instruct him carefully to watch Walter Smith and report immediately upon waking, demonstrating protective vigilance and responsibility.
Turns away from others when startled by the phone call, showing momentary fear but no hostility or coldness.
Addresses the house via public address system, asking occupants to call him if safe

Shows concern for Thomas's safety and clearly states he does not want him to get hurt.
Communicates sincerely and patiently with Thomas, explaining the situation and asking for help carefully.

Considers and discusses a risky plan involving getting disks through a child in a hostile environment, showing strategic thinking but relying on uncertain factors.
Shows concern for Thomas' safety repeatedly, which displays good situational awareness but also suggests some caution or hesitance that might slow action.
